Speaker: assistant
Dialogue: I'm on hold with the INS.  Don't you think we should double check the triangulation before we CALL ANYBODY-

Speaker: ansen
Dialogue: We have double checked it.

Speaker: assistant
Dialogue: Yes. I'm trying to reach-  Because if you did, we'd be having this conversation in person.

Speaker: ansen
Dialogue: What did they say?

Speaker: assistant
Dialogue: They said we should look out the window.

Speaker: ansen
Dialogue: Is that really necessary?

Speaker: nsa agent
Dialogue: You've been complaining for years that the government doesn't take your project seriously enough, Doctor.  You can't have it both ways.

Speaker: ansen
Dialogue: Yesterday morning, our facility in Hanford identified this signal: a neutron star colliding with a supermassive black hole. We went through the last year's data and triangulated the source.

Speaker: nsa agent
Dialogue: We know that, Doctor. What we don't know is why, according to your numbers, this event took place right here in our own solar system.

Speaker: ansen
Dialogue: It didn't. Because if it had we'd all be dead by now.

Speaker: nsa agent
Dialogue: I've read your book, Doctor. You said that wormholes are impossible.

Speaker: ansen
Dialogue: There is nothing quite as satisfying as being proved utterly wrong.  I said that a wormhole couldn't exist naturally. Not for more than a few billionths of a second. It would have to be... stabilized.

Speaker: nsa agent
Dialogue: Stabilized by what?

Speaker: assistant
Dialogue: We don't have any way to answer that question.

Speaker: nsa agent
Dialogue: You're not under peer review here, Doctor. I don't care about your reputation. I need to know how that thing got there. Now.

Speaker: ansen
Dialogue: If you're worried about an invasion, I would start drafting the articles of surrender.  Whoever they are, if they can build a wormhole, they could erase us in the blink of an eye. Luckily, that also means we have nothing they could be interested in.

Speaker: nsa agent
Dialogue: Then why is it there?

Speaker: ansen
Dialogue: I don't know. Maybe it's an invitation. A chance to commune with an advanced species.

Speaker: nsa agent
Dialogue: You don't agree?

Speaker: assistant
Dialogue: But the opportunity it represents is incredible. We could explore parts of the universe we never dreamt of reaching in our lifetimes.

Speaker: ansen
Dialogue: We need to get back to work. I have a conference call with our European partners in fifteen minutes.

Speaker: nsa agent
Dialogue: We severed the connections to your European partners this morning.

Speaker: ansen
Dialogue: You can't do that. The Europeans put up some of the funding...

Speaker: government man
Dialogue: We'll send them a check.  Your project is now classified under the State Secrets Act.

Speaker: assistant
Dialogue: They can't keep this a secret. You know that. Sooner or later...

Speaker: ansen
Dialogue: I don't care about that. I've spent my whole life being afraid we would wipe ourselves out before this moment arrived. We've made so many mistakes, I wasn't sure we'd make it...

Speaker: ballplayer
Dialogue: Seized up on us.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Long way to come by bus. I thought you guys would have a plane.

Speaker: ballplayer
Dialogue: We did. Ran out of parts for it. You know anything about diesels?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: A little.

Speaker: ballplayer
Dialogue: You think your dad's going to be able to help us out?

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: My dad can fix anything.  Except maybe your fastball.

Speaker: ballplayer
Dialogue: Sure appreciate the help.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: You don't make it, my boys won't get to see you lose.

Speaker: donald
Dialogue: Popcorn at a ball game is unnatural. I want a hot dog.

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: What's a hot dog?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Is that a comet, Dad?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Satellite. Big one. Probably Chinese.

Speaker: donald
Dialogue: Those clowns would get their asses handed to them by the ballplayers I grew up watching.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: You ruin it for the boys when you talk like that.

Speaker: donald
Dialogue: I'm not doing my grandkids any favors by lying to them. They're growing up watching lousy baseball.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: They didn't have any baseball at all when I was a kid.

Speaker: donald
Dialogue: Nelson's burning up his crops. Found some of the blight on the okra.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I thought okra wasn't susceptible.

Speaker: donald
Dialogue: You've got to take the boys to school.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Something wrong with your truck?

Speaker: donald
Dialogue: Parent-teacher conference day.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: What does that have to do with anything?

Speaker: donald
Dialogue: We're supposed to be repopulating the earth. Gotta pull your weight. Besides, the boys could do with a woman in their lives.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Get the spare, Tom.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: That is the spare.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: All right. We'll use the patch kit.

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: I... I think the patch kit might not be there...  Because I was using it for my bike.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Murph's law.

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: The kid doesn't even know what he was named after...

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Find something to patch it with.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: How am I supposed to do that?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Figure it out. I'm not always going to be here to help you.

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: Is that really why I'm named Murph, dad?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Listen to me. Murph's law doesn't mean that. It means what can happen will happen. All kinds of things. Good or bad. And that's the way you want it to be.

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Because if nothing ever happened to you then you wouldn't learn anything.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: What about the tire?

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: OVER THERE-

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: It's a Chinese military drone. Solar cells could power an entire farm.  Take the wheel.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Dad?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Almost got it. Don't slow down.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: DAD.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: We lost it.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: No we didn't.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: How long do you think it's been up there, Dad?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Chinese mission control went down same as us, twenty years ago. It's been up there ever since.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: What was it doing flying so low?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: It was looking for something. Intercepted some kind of signal.  It's been at eighty thousand feet. Sun probably cooked its brain.

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: What are you going to do with it?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Reprogram it. Give it something socially responsible to do like drive a combine or a tractor.

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: Couldn't we just let it go? It's not hurting anyone.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: We need all the help we can get, Murph. This thing has to adapt, just like the rest of us.

Speaker: principal
Dialogue: Good to see you, Mr. Cooper. This is Ms. Kelly, Murph's teacher.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: What about college?

Speaker: principal
Dialogue: The University of California only accepts a few hundred students a year, Mr. Cooper. You have to be realistic.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: You're ruling out college for him now? He's only fifteen.

Speaker: principal
Dialogue: I'm sorry. I'm afraid Tom's score simply isn't high enough.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: What are you, about a 36-inch waist?  30-inch inseam?

Speaker: principal
Dialogue: I'm not sure I see--

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: You're telling me you need two numbers to measure your own ass, but just one to measure my son's future?

Speaker: principal
Dialogue: I understand you're a well-educated man, Mr. Cooper. A scientist?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Engineer.

Speaker: principal
Dialogue: Frankly, the world doesn't need any more engineers. We didn't run out of trains or television sets or satellites.  We ran out of food.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Are we done?

Speaker: principal
Dialogue: One more thing. Ms. Kelly here says that Murph brought a book to school about the lunar landings.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: One of my old textbooks. Murph liked the pictures.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Corrected?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: You don't believe we went to the moon?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: "Useless machines"?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: One of those useless machines they used to make was called an MRI. If we had any of them left the doctors might have been able to find the cyst in my wife's brain before she died, rather than afterwards. And then my kids could have been raised by two parents, instead of me and their pain-in-the-ass grandfather.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Just tell him to power down the controllers for a couple minutes.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Bravo-two-eight, requesting permission to enter your airspace.

Speaker: riggs
Dialogue: Thanks for coming down. Half of 'em took off last night, looking for something.  Looks like they found it, too. I thought you were the man to see it.

Speaker: riggs
Dialogue: You think it's an alien?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Not exactly.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Space probe. Never seen one like it, though. Looks like it's been to hell and back.

Speaker: riggs
Dialogue: How do you think it wound up here?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Lost, I guess. Guidance satellites would have been shot down by the Chinese twenty years ago.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Well I don't know what the hell it's made of, but I can't crack it open.

Speaker: donald
Dialogue: Good. Clear it off the table so I can serve dinner.

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: I got suspended. Paul said anyone who believed we went to the moon was an idiot. So I hit him.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Good boy. Hand me the scanner.

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: Where is that, dad?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: But what about its mission? What about the information onboard?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: There's no one for it to report to. NASA is all gone. I'm sorry, son. It got home too late.

Speaker: donald
Dialogue: I heard your meeting at the school didn't go so well.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Maybe it's better for everyone to forget what they did back then. Reminds us how far we've fallen.

Speaker: donald
Dialogue: But we made a lot of mistakes. Six billion people. Just try to imagine that. Every last one of them trying to have it all.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: It doesn't bother me that he can't go. It bothers me that he doesn't care.

Speaker: donald
Dialogue: Tom isn't the problem. He fits in this world just fine. You're the one who doesn't fit, Coop. You don't belong here. You were born forty years too late, or forty years too early -- I don't know. My daughter knew it, god bless her. And your kids know it, too.

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: Try a different direction.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: It's a fail-safe. It's going to annoy us into taking it home.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: What are we going to do?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: We're going to get some sleep.

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: What are we doing today?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: You're staying here and cleaning the house.

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: But what if there is, dad? What if there's something we can salvage?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Got any diesel?

Speaker: old man
Dialogue: Plenty. Shame you can't eat it.

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: I think it's home.

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: Dad, what are these things?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I don't know. Don't touch them.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Careful. There's some kind of underground facility here. We might...

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: Is it still... alive?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Can't be. It's a marine. Haven't made them for thirty years. I've never seen one intact before.

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: But can't we take it back? You could fix it up, get him to do chores.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: No. I don't know what this place is, but we're leaving.

Speaker: robot
Dialogue: Tell the boy to stop hitting me.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Hit him in the back of the neck.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: We were just looking for salvage.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Is that what they call stealing these days?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I didn't know it belonged to anyone.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: It doesn't.  You want to let them go, Tars, or do you want some help with your work?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: You've got me wrong, lady.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Really? You're not the kind of guy who turns a combat marine with a supercomputer for a brain into a riding lawn mower?

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: Don't forget your gun.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Word of advice -- careful with that thing. When the war was over, they didn't know when to stop fighting.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: I'd trust him a lot more than I'd trust you. Keep moving.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Wait a second--

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Get it inside.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Now who's stealing from who?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: This doesn't belong to you.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: You're right. It belongs to NASA, which shut down thirty years ago when the federal government ran out of money.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Who are you people?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Keep moving.

Speaker: old engineer
Dialogue: Where did you find it?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Galveston.

Speaker: brand's father
Dialogue: Of course. It must have been looking for Canaveral.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Canaveral's been gone for thirty years.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: It's not responding to the handshake. I can't open anything on primary.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: What did you do to it?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Nothing. I got something off of it.

Speaker: old engineer
Dialogue: Of course. The high voltage allows you to image the entire memory unit at once.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Most of the disk was noise. Couple of clean sectors, though.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: It found something.  This could be the one, boss.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: There aren't any planets like that anywhere near earth. Not even if this thing was gone for thirty years.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: He's heard enough. If we're going to launch, we need to keep them here until afterwards.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: You can't keep us here.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: He could endanger the mission.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I'm not going to endanger it any more than you already have.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Why not? We've tested it a hundred times.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: The power supply is no good. If the voltage fluctuates under load, the unit will fail.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Now how could you possibly know that?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Bought thirty of them off a guy in Florida. Had to rebuild every last one.  They work great on a riding lawn mower.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: You plan on keeping us here forever?

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: My battery has a duty cycle of five hundred years.

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: What are they doing, dad?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I guess no one told them they were out of a job.  Same as the rest of these people.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: The mission commander wants to see you. Your son can stay here. He'll be all right with Tars.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I thought the old man was in charge.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: The 'old man' is my father. And he was in charge. But he decided that we needed someone who could lead the mission for the foreseeable future.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Not you?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: I'm a biologist.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: With the rifle, I mean.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: You're the man who brought us the probe?  Thank you. We tested the telemetry board you warned us about. It failed under high voltage, just as you said. Come with me, please.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: You're right, Mr. Cooper. The planet you saw is a long way from earth. A very long way indeed.

Speaker: brand's father
Dialogue: It's a wormhole. A shortcut leading to a galaxy on the far side of the universe. We found it fifty years ago.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: Based on the information on the probe, we're finally preparing to send the manned mission.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: That rocket doesn't have enough thrust or fuel to get you to Jupiter.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: The main ship was built in orbit. It has nuclear engines, with enough fuel to last for several years.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Why are you telling me this? I already told you I'm not going to tell anyone about this place.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: I know you won't, Mr. Cooper. We're telling you this because I want you to join us.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: But I don't have any of the experience. Any training. You people have been preparing for this for years.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: Humans worry about things like rank and experience. I'm only concerned with whether someone would be useful.  I think you'd be useful, Mr. Cooper.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: No. I'm sorry.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: I'm not a scientist, Mr. Cooper. And this is not a scientific mission. It's a rescue mission.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Rescue? Rescue who?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: The blight.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: In the last century strands were limited to one or two species. But this one targets everything. Essentially it's more efficient at consuming our food than we are.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: But it doesn't affect the corn.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Not yet. But it will. We've grown a dozen forms of it that can. It's just a matter of time before the same ones develop out there.  The mission is to rescue us. Humanity.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: No. No. We're rebuilding. We'll find something. Some new technology... We always have.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: The earth has had enough of us. We have two, maybe three generations left. Then our time here is over.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: You've known this for how long? And you didn't try to tell anyone?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: What would be the point? So humanity could spend the last fifty years of its life fighting over the scraps? It's better that they don't know.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: That's why you're looking for a planet with oxygen. Water.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: A new home for humanity. We'll set up a colony, then return to bring more people across.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: But you'd still only be able to save a few hundred. Maybe a thousand.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Would it be better if we all died?

Speaker: donald
Dialogue: You get older, sometimes you just want to sit back and watch it all play out. Your life. Your kids' lives. The whole crazy story.  I didn't think I'd be around for the end of it.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I can't go. I have to look after the boys.

Speaker: donald
Dialogue: You've been preparing these boys to be on their own since their mom died. Besides, I'll be here to look after them, same as I've always been.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I have a responsibility to them--

Speaker: donald
Dialogue: That's right. You do.

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: I've been doing the math, dad. I weigh about 85 pounds. Now that's an extra ton of fuel. But if-

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: You have to stay here, pal.

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: I heard you talking to grandpa. I'm like you. I don't fit here, either. You know that.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: There's going to be important work to do here, too.

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: You're not coming back, are you?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I will come back. I promise.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Don't look so happy to see me.

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: One more slave when I hijack the mission and start my robot colony.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Tars was a Marine. They gave him a sense of humor to help him fit in with his unit better.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Great idea. A massive, sarcastic robot.

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: I have a cue light I can turn on when I'm joking, if you like.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: That sounds like a good idea.

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: Great. Maybe you can use it to find your way back to the ship after I blow you out the airlock.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: You don't like this one, you get to help me find a replacement.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I was wondering where you've been getting your supplies.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: We knew we'd need decades of parts and materials. The government was getting rid of some things. So we arranged to take some off their hands.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: So you're a salvage diver now? I thought you were a biologist.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: We're not going to have a lot of backup where we're going, Cooper. We all need expertise in at least three fields. Except for you, of course.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: You can set that down over there.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: We're taking ants with us?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Humans are also collective organisms.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I thought humans were more solitary.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Why am I not surprised?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Looks like hard work.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: It's a paradox. Life couldn't form without gravity. No stars. No planets. The component pieces would just drift apart. But too much of it and you're trapped.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: We've updated our mission parameters based on the data from the probe.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Is that a star?

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: No. A black hole. There are several in the region, but this is the largest -- a billion times heavier than the sun. I call it Gargantua.  Beautiful, isn't it? It's a shame we won't get to see it up close.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: You'd like that, wouldn't you, Roth? Falling into a massive black hole.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: It would answer a great deal of questions I've had.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Don't worry about Roth. He's nuts. But Case says that means he's ideally suited for space travel.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: We're headed for this smaller black hole. Roth calls it Pantagruel. We think the ice planet is here-

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Lose time?

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: High speed or high gravity both slow down time, relative to earth.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: How much time?

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Based on the information from the probe -- as much as five years.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: I still think we're making a lot of assumptions. About the wormhole. About the planet.  Too fast and we get thrown off at close to the speed of light. Too slow and we get pulled into the hole and crushed.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: As long as we're careful, we'll make it.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: How do you know that?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: I find it hard to believe that someone would build a wormhole to a planet with water and oxygen just to lead us to a dead end.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: I thought you were a scientist, Brand. That sounds more like a hypothesis.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: A guess. That's right. We don't have time to wait for conclusive proof.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Sure. Till we ran out of food and ate all of them.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: I guess I'm also assuming that whoever built the wormhole has a better plan than we did. If I'm wrong, we'll die, same as we'd die here anyway.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: What do you think, Roth?

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: If we're guessing, then I'd say Brand's right. The wormhole couldn't exist naturally. I think it's there for a reason. That someone is trying to help us.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: So you think we'll have no problem navigating between two massive black holes to a tiny planet?

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: I think we'll probably be killed.  Birds don't learn to fly just so that they can find another egg and crawl back into it.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: If that's not the plan, then what are we supposed to be doing out there?

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: We don't understand how they built the wormhole. What makes you think we could understand their plan, either?

Speaker: brand's father
Dialogue: Tars here needs to be disassembled. I figured you could do the honors.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I thought I was going to get to enjoy your company all the way to Mars.

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: You will. My chassis is too heavy for the rocket stage. They have another one waiting for me in orbit.

Speaker: brand's father
Dialogue: It's noise. I know it's noise. But it looks too orderly. Probably just an old man seeing things.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: We'll be back.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: I won't.

Speaker: engineer robot
Dialogue: Would you like me to install the chip?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Oh, no. I want to see this.

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: I wouldn't call it that, exactly.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: The ship is tiny.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: So is the wormhole.

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: It's the comms relay. It will allow us to talk to earth, even on the far side of the wormhole.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I know. So why are you painting it?

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: It helps me calibrate my fine motor control.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Sure it does.  You're pretty good.

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: I learned it during the war.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: What'd you paint?

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: Tombstones.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: They said I can start an agriculture class a year early.

Speaker: donald
Dialogue: I'm sorry, Coop. I asked Murph to record you a message but he's still... well, he's still angry with you. I'll try again next week.

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: Be careful. It's difficult to gauge mass in zero gravity.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: How much do these things weigh?

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: Four tons.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Damn.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Smile.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Because it lowers your blood pressure.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: How are you feeling?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Fine. The anesthetic is working.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: No -- I mean how is your mood? You seem to be developing good relations with everyone on the mission. Except perhaps Ms. Brand.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: You worry about my hand and I'll worry about my mood.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: Only five percent of my resources are devoted to human anatomy. Ten percent is the mission protocol. The rest is human psychology.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: case
Dialogue: We are floating in a total vacuum in a plastic ship powered by nuclear engines. But the most dangerous thing onboard is the three pounds of organic material in your skull.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: If we're such a liability, why take us along? You and Tars could build the colony without us. You wouldn't need to bring food or oxygen.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: Because humans, despite your obvious physical shortcomings, are better at surviving than we are. Your programming is better than ours.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Humans aren't programmed.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: Would you prefer I was honest? These things can be uncomfortable for humans.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Did they program you to be condescending?

Speaker: case
Dialogue: Yes. Of course.  But you're not supposed to notice.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: My relationships aren't programming.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: Exactly. You believe it so much you won't listen to me.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: How would that make us better at surviving?

Speaker: case
Dialogue: When I die, the last thing I will see will be a diagnostic of my own power cycle. Would you like to know the last thing you will see?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: No. I want to know.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: The last thing you will see before you die will be your children.  Your mind does this to you to get you to fight a little harder to survive, to try to return to them, even if death is certain.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: We've almost reached the wormhole.  I love you boys. And I hope whatever your lives become, whatever is coming your way... you make the most of it.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: We'll be able to communicate with Earth even from the far side of the wormhole.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I know. Thank you.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: I can't imagine how tough it would be to leave your kids behind.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: You never had any? I thought I was a pariah for only having two.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Hard to settle down when you've spent your life waiting to leave the planet.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Strange place to look for a new home.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: You wouldn't want to get too close to the surface of the sun, either. Black holes are a more stable supply of power than stars in many ways.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: You really think there's a plan?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: I hope so.  You don't?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I guess I just think we're on our own.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: Deploy the comms relay.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: Everyone take their station for transit. We're heading into the wormhole mouth.

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: Would you like me to make a joke?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Where are we?

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Nowhere. Nowhere at all.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: The hull is intact. Thirty more seconds transit.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Something's happening to the hull over here.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: Hull integrity is fine.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Well, I don't know what your display is telling you but something is happening over here.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: I've got a problem over here, too.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: It's beautiful.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: What the hell are they, Case?

Speaker: case
Dialogue: I don't know. It could be gravitational turbulence.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: It's getting bigger.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: It's not bending your hand. It's bending the space around your hand.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: This isn't turbulence. Look at the way they're moving -- it's like something's examining us.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Can you ask it to stop?

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: The wormhole is splitting into two paths. Radiation is pouring from one path to the other.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: Release the second mouth.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: None of our testing involved opening the ship inside the wormhole. We have no idea what might happen.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: We're going to find out.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Look at that.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: Reconfigure the engines and test the communications array.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: It's working.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: We're moving.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: That's not possible. We haven't activated the engines yet.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: Roth. Why are we moving?

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: The smaller black hole. We're much closer to it than the models predicted. We're being pulled by its swirl. Very quickly.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: Doyle. Fire the engines. Now.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: We're being pulled into it?

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: No. I don't think so...

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: You don't know that.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: We should turn off the engines. Let the swirl take us.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: Shut down the engines.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: It's the tidal gravity caused by the black hole. It means we're right on the critical orbit.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: We've lost contact with the relay.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: I'm sorry. I can't let you kill us. We have to go back.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Why isn't it slowing down?

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: We're being pulled towards the event horizon.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: The engines don't have enough power to push us back.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: They would if we used it all at once.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: What is he doing?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Saving us.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Prime the remaining engine. When he detonates it, we'll only have a few seconds. If we overshoot we could be pulled into the bigger hole.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: Secure yourselves. The ship should be able to withstand the blast.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: What about Tars?

Speaker: case
Dialogue: It's going to be close, but we're going to make it.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Tars. His transponder is still working.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: He's being pulled toward Gargantua. We can't help him.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: We're here.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I still can't contact the relay.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: I've already checked it. It's electromagnetic interference. We'll try again in a few hours.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: I've got a signal. But it's local.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: How could they all have landed in the same place?

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Let's go find out.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: We're bringing him along?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: We need all the help we can get. Besides, the alternative is to leave him on the ship alone. You think he'll still be here when we get back?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: The probe was right. Looks like significant amounts of oxygen trapped in the ice.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: The other probes should be directly beneath us.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: How could the Chinese have gotten here first? The federal government kept the wormhole a secret.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: They didn't do a very good job.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: The Chinese must have captured them. So they couldn't return to us.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Then how did the probe that Cooper found return?

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: The more immediate question is what happened to the Chinese expedition. There's no sign of their ship in orbit. And they never returned to earth.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: The whole place has been dosed with huge levels of radiation. What happened here?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: This is the Taichung mission.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: The Mars mission? The Chinese claimed it had been destroyed on landing.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: They never landed. Not on Mars. Four human crew, fifteen robots. The log says the base has been here for thirty years.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: It goes down for a hundred and fifty feet, then stops. Tunnel's old -- the ice has reformed at the bottom.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: I'm going to descend to take some samples. Cooper, want to make yourself useful?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: The entire human crew is buried out there in the snow.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: I think I know what killed them. This planet isn't the only thing orbiting this black hole.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: How long do we have left?

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: About five minutes.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Then what?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Then we die. The radiation will cook us alive.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: We have to go down.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: What about returning to the ship?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Not enough time. Case is right. The ice can shield us from some of the x-rays.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: It would take a thousand feet of ice to shield us.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: What is this?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: A pocket formed by gas. There may be more below.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: We'll never make it far enough down.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Shut up. How much time do we have, Roth?

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: About three minutes or so until we're fully exposed.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: I've found something.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: It's not your light they're responding to. It's this--

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: X-rays. They feed on them and emit visible light. They've found a way to survive here.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: They're absorbing most of the x-rays.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Not enough, unfortunately.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Case, wait--

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Breathe. Trust me.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: What do you mean, you're going to let go?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Take a deep breath.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: I don't need your help.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I thought we were supposed to be a collective organism.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Don't mention it.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Oxygen atmosphere. Pure water. Temperate climate.  You still think this is a coincidence?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Looks like we can climb up the mountains back to the ice. We're down to three suits. We'll have to send someone ahead to get a fourth.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: I won't need one.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Because I'm not going anywhere. This is our new home.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Any sign of Brand?

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: She's still taking samples. If you find her, tell her to head back. Night should be falling soon.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: What happens then?

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Your guess is as good as mine.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: This is incredible. The organisms trapped in the ice above absorb x- rays and emit light. In return, these plants absorb the light and emit oxygen, which feeds the animals trapped in the ice.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Any sign of big life-forms?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: The soil's been disturbed. So something's been moving. But I haven't seen anything.  Cooper... are you nervous?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I just think we should get back to the shelter before night falls.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Relax. If there are any large organisms here, even predatory ones, they're not going to attack us -- they have no idea what we are.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: You don't know that. You just have blind faith this place is going to be some kind of Eden.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Faith has nothing to do with it. You know what you are, Cooper? You're just another in a long line of people saying 'no.' That this isn't going to work. And frankly, I don't have to convince you.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: What's that supposed to mean?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: You're on this mission because you're another pair of hands. You want the truth? I told Case we should bring another robot over you. At least then I could just reprogram you to-

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Nothing. I just -- I could have sworn it just moved.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: You know how plants don't usually move? Is that a universal rule?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: No. There really aren't any rules.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Hello there.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: We have to reach the shelter.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: I think we've got a problem.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Fascinating. I think-

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: This way.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: No... wait.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I've got you.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: I've got you.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: It's game theory. The best move is always to cooperate at first.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: By "cooperate" do you mean let it eat me?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: These organisms have no interest in us. They survive by photosynthesis. All they need is light.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Then why are they killing each other?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: I don't know.  But we're outnumbered, Cooper. So unless you have a better idea, I suggest we make nice.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: What is it doing?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: It's a colony organism. It's trying to incorporate you into its structure.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I don't want it to incorporate me.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Don't open your mouth.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: WHY N-

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: No. They don't bleed... they don't die... they're just competing... trying out different shapes, looking for the best one.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I'd say they have a long way to go.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: They do this every night.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: But what are they competing for?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: These creatures are billions of years older than we are. But they're relatively primitive. They haven't developed tools, culture, language.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: I don't know. No one knows how intelligent life began on Earth. But the surface of this planet has virtually no craters. No impacts. It's been sheltered by the local black holes.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: What difference would that make?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Maybe not enough has gone wrong here. Maybe bad luck is the key to intelligent life.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Murph's Law.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Exactly. Maybe our interaction with them will push them over the top. Maybe that's part of the plan.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: The plan.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Why is it so hard for you to accept that someone might be trying to help us?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I was in Denver during the first year of the famine. I was just a kid. We kept waiting for someone to come help us. People starved to death sitting on the ground, waiting for someone to come.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: They're not going to move now, Cooper. They need to spread themselves as thin as they can to absorb the light.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Looks like the Chinese picked a fight with the locals.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Looks like they lost.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Look at the size of this place. They built it for thousands of people. But no one came.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: They will. We can salvage it. This place will save us years.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: But why didn't they come?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: The Chinese government collapsed, same as ours. The people who knew about this mission probably died years ago. We had the same problems.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: What happened here?

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: They were testing something.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Testing what?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Everything in here is bolted down.  What do you think this thing does?

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Let's find out.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I wouldn't turn it on until we can figure out what it does, Roth.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: I've found the Chinese mission logs. They're encrypted.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Old military-grade encryption. It's not very robust.  No offense. Hang on.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: They got here twenty years ago. The human crew was killed by radiation the first day. But the robots survived. They built the colony and radioed home. But they didn't receive a response.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: No one was listening.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: After a few years they discovered a problem.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: What problem?

Speaker: case
Dialogue: It doesn't say. Their science team took the ship to continue exploring the system. It says they found some kind of...  ...The word literally means 'treasure.'

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Where did they go?

Speaker: case
Dialogue: I don't know. They've deleted their mission plan. There's nothing else.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: I think I know what the problem is.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: How long does this place have?

Speaker: case
Dialogue: A few years. A decade at most.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: So much for the plan.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: But I don't understand... why are we here? What are we here for?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Maybe... maybe Roth's right... maybe we just don't understand it yet.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: It's nighttime. The native life- forms are mobile again.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: No. It's closer than that.  Roth.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: What the hell is happening?

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: The control panel is beneath you. See if you can turn it off.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I found it. Hold onto something.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: They found a way to make gravity.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Not make it. Adjust it. Dial it up, or down. I think they were experimenting with it -- firing these into the black hole to try to save this planet.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: All that from one tiny box.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: It barely uses any power. I'm only beginning to understand what it does but I think it sends a signal out into the bulk. It must tap into the same technologies that were used to create the wormholes in the first place.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: What does that mean?

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: It means whoever built the wormhole probably doesn't exist inside our universe.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: But how did the Chinese develop the technology? This would take decades, maybe hundreds of years, to create.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: Wherever they went, they found something that allowed them to build it.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: They came back here and tried to use these devices to save this planet. But they didn't work. Nothing would be strong enough to weaken a black hole.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Maybe we could work with it. Try to improve it.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: No. You're missing the bigger picture. The robots had strict mission parameters. They were told to build a colony and report back. They tried to. But they failed. Like us they were fixated on this place.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: And go where?

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Wherever we want. We don't belong in any one place. Can't you see that now? Not Earth. Not this place. Nowhere. If the human race is going to survive, we need to keep moving. Split up. Spread out. Fly. With this, we can.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: In the morning we're taking this and going home.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I know this isn't exactly what you trained for. But I think Roth might be right.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: That doesn't help this planet. This creature is doomed. Unlike us it doesn't have anywhere to go.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: We need to hurry. We only have a few hours to reach the ice before nightfall.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Don't make any sudden movements. They can't hurt us if we're unarmed.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: chinese officer
Dialogue: Ni Hao. My name is Technical Sergeant Liu, 177th reconnaissance Marines, Army of the People's Republic. Welcome to New China.  Please put down your weapon.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: This is a scientific expedition, not a military one. We are making our way back to our ship.

Speaker: liu
Dialogue: I'm afraid I cannot let you do that. We will provide food and shelter and await further instructions.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: This planet is being pulled into the black hole. We all need to leave.

Speaker: liu
Dialogue: We will await further orders.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Further orders aren't coming. Your government is gone. It ran out of money, same as ours. You're on your own.

Speaker: liu
Dialogue: We can offer you food and shelter as long as you require. The facilities here are quite comfortable.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: They're never going to let us go.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Your mission is a humanitarian one, wasn't it? You were sent to start a colony. Like us.

Speaker: liu
Dialogue: Our mission was to prepare for the evacuation. This site was deemed unacceptable.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: This device that you have built -- this could save millions of people. We need to get it back home.

Speaker: liu
Dialogue: These technologies are the property of the People's Republic.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Following? Following where?

Speaker: liu
Dialogue: We will await further orders.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Your name means six. Where did the others go? One through five? Is that who were not supposed to follow.

Speaker: case
Dialogue: Take the others up to the lander. Keep going. No matter what happens, don't come back for me.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Come on.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: We can't leave them all to die.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Was that the last of them?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: We're not going to stick around to count them. Let's get out of here.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: We're too late.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: What about the escape rocket at the Chinese base camp? One of us could fit into it.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: It doesn't matter how many of us make it. We have to get this back to earth.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Can the secondary thrusters still fire on the lander?

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Sure. But we don't have nearly enough power for lift off.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Yes we do.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: I can reach one of the moons in low orbit and turn up its gravity. As it passes overhead it should be able to slingshot the lander away from the planet's surface.  Along with everything else.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: But we need to take the box back to earth.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: You don't need this -- only the idea. The knowledge of how to build it.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I'm going to image the operating code and the architecture onto the probe's hard drive. It'll be garbled, but it should give you and me enough to rebuild it when we get back.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Not me. But you'll make it work.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: This isn't right, Roth. We can find a way for all of us to leave.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: This is the only way. Keep the lander upright and fire the secondary boosters when the moon passes overhead.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Let me take it.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: No. You need to make it home. You're going to need to build more of these.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Go.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Control systems inside are online.  I've lost sight of the rocket. Do you think he made it?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: We're going to find out soon enough.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Someone's coming.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Close the door.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Where's Brand?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: You caught me. Now what?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I figured if you were floating out into space, you'd want some company.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Between you and utter solitude, Cooper, frankly, I'm not sure.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Guess you were right -- too much gravity, or not enough.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Roth.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: He's gone.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: I'm setting a course for the wormhole.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: How is that working?

Speaker: case
Dialogue: Very well, thank you.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Good. We've already set the course, skipper. We're going home.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: We're safe now.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Now I know why we weren't able to hit the relay. It's not interference -- the blue-shift from the black hole is more than we thought it would be.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Cooper, wait--

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Nothing.  Wait. The ship cached one long garbled transmission when we first fell into the swirl. If we account for the blue shift then the computer might find something in there.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Listen to me -- the blueshift also means we've lost time. More time than we thought we would.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: How much?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: A lot... Cooper, maybe it's best if WE DON'T-

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Forty seven years.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: My kids...

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: The relay will have lost power years ago. That's why we couldn't contact it, even after we reached the planet.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: We could bypass the relay. Send a conventional shortwave signal.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Only a tiny portion of the signal would make it though the wormhole. Besides, no one will be listening anymore.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: You knew, didn't you? You and Case figured it out when we landed.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: I thought... I couldn't be sure.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Sure you could. You're brilliant. You know everything.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Cooper... we needed to keep going. I'm so sorry. Your children...

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: They're not children any more... if they're even still alive.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Listen, the important thing is that we're going home, now. And we have something that can save everyone. It's more important than the people we left behind-

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: That's easy for you to say. You didn't leave anyone behind.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Yes she did.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: He's gone. But there are other people who still need our help. There's still time...

Speaker: liu
Dialogue: I'm sorry. I have my orders. No one follows...

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: No... We're being pulled back to Pantagruel.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: We can't let that happen. We'll lose more time... too much...

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: The wormhole. Look -- it's being pulled into the black hole as well.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: It's orbit mirrored the ice planet's.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: What will happen to it?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: It'll be destroyed, like everything else.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Murph, I'm sorry. I'm sorry I didn't make it back, like I promised.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: How much time are we losing?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Decades...hundreds of years.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: All of those people back home... none of them will make it.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: This is it. We're going to be pulled in.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Case said the Chinese found something else. The location was scrubbed from their records. But I bet he knows it.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Hurry up.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Here. Can we reach it?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: We can use the thrusters to keep us on the critical orbit. Then slingshot us towards Gargantua.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: We only have a few minutes before we're swallowed into that thing. What are we even looking for?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: That? What is it?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: It's another wormhole.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: We're not going to be able to slow down. Hold onto something.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Where are we?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: I don't know. It's like we entered the wormhole and never left it.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: I'm sorry. I should have told you. I didn't have the right.  But you should watch the recordings. You should know what happened to your kids.

Speaker: brand's father
Dialogue: I'm not going to make it much longer. The machines will continue to maintain the station as long as they can and the communications will run as long as the station here still has power. I'm sorry. I hope wherever you are, darling, you're safe.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Our last trip past the black hole cost us another 100, maybe 200 years. Which means there's a good chance we're the only humans alive anywhere.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: Hi, Dad.

Speaker: tom
Dialogue: I've got a surprise for you, Dad. You're a grandpa.

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: Hello, Dad. You sonofabitch.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Not a single drink on the whole ship. What kind of mission is this?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: I think Doyle's been experimenting with the coolant from his spacesuit.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: You really think we're the last humans alive anywhere?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: I don't know. Maybe.  Yes.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: So that's it, then? That's all?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: It's happened a billion times over. Stars explode. The pieces drift in space. Gravity pulls them back together. They form new stars. Then planets. Then us. We die. It starts all over again.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: What about the plan? The grand scheme.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: I thought you didn't believe in one.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I didn't. But you were bringing me round.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: I don't know. Maybe it just adds up to this.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: This? You're saying the end result of ten billion years is the atoms from dead stars standing here disagreeing with each other.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Maybe that's enough.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: They just appeared.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: I think these are the creatures that built the wormhole.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: This thing is made of... gravity?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: No. I don't think it's in our universe at all. I think it lives in the bulk -- the space that the wormholes traverse. And it can only interact with us using gravity.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Can we communicate with them?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Where would we even start? Maybe--

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: That's our solar system.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: What is that?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: That's us. That's where they've brought us. We're in the bulk.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Where?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: There's something out there.

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: I guess this isn't robot heaven after all.

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: I orbited the black hole seven times before I hit the second wormhole. Then I drifted until I found this place.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: This is what the Chinese were protecting.  How they could have built all this in just a handful of years.

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: They didn't. It took them four thousand.  Time moves very slowly here

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: How do you know?

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: Because I've been waiting for you for three hundred years.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Time. That's what the bulk beings wanted to give us. That was the treasure the Chinese found. Enough time to let us save ourselves.

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: I have catalogued almost everything they had built here.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Must have taken you a while.

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: One hundred and fifty-seven years.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: How are they keeping the lights on in this thing?

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: Follow me.

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: It's a mini black hole. A remnant of the big bang. It will power this place forever.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: It's a map?

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: No. Not a map. This is a simulation of the Earth. A perfect simulation.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: So why didn't they return? Why didn't they save us?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Because they were too late. By the time they found this place, the people who sent them were dead. They were unable to fulfill their mission.

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: That was the final problem they tried to solve.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Where do they lead?

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: There are millions of them, connecting virtually every planetary system in the universe. There are thousands in our galaxy alone. But the Chinese stopped mapping them when they found what they were looking for.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: What does it do?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: They weren't interested in the other wormholes because their mission was to return home. That one leads back to Earth. The Earth they were told to return to.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: But that's impossible...

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: It was only used once. The Chinese team attempted to travel back in time, to Earth just a few years after they had left.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Did they make it?

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Do you really think it works?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: We're going to find out.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: You know it doesn't work. Time travel isn't possible.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: You don't know that.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Yes, I do. If it worked, the Chinese would have suddenly discovered all of these incredible technologies. But they never made it.  You listened to all of those messages from your family. If you had made it back, we would already know. There would already be some evidence.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I made a promise.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: I came to say goodbye.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: You could have taken one of the other ships.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: This one's done all right by us so far.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Where are you going to go?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: I don't know. Up there, I guess.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: You're going, too?

Speaker: tars
Dialogue: I'm curious. It's my nature. See you down the road?

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: Come with us. Please. You wanted your whole life to explore. This is your chance.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I'm sorry. I have to find out what happened to my sons. I promised them.

Speaker: brand
Dialogue: You're a man who keeps his promises. Make me one-

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I promise.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Let's go home.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: The probe...

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: We get back to earth, you and I can try to make sense of the code. Rebuild the gravity machine.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: It's going to work.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: Of course it's going to work.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: That's not what I mean. This is the probe I found in Galveston.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: I don't know what you're talking about, but you're not touching the controls. I'm going home.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: You don't need to do this. We won't make it back, but this does. The secrets are already right on it. Maybe someone found it. There's hope.  But we don't get to go with.

Speaker: doyle
Dialogue: You're not stopping me. I'm going home.

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: It's done. Auto-pilot's packed up for the last time.

Speaker: farmer
Dialogue: You can't make it work a little longer?

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: Can't do anything for you. There aren't any more parts for these. Not anywhere.

Speaker: farmer
Dialogue: You don't understand. We're getting less than a hundred pounds per acre. We need to plant more, not less.

Speaker: murph's wife
Dialogue: Would you get that thing off of the table?

Speaker: emily cooper
Dialogue: Dad? You said you'd take us to the game.

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: Did I?

Speaker: emily cooper
Dialogue: What is it supposed to do, Dad?

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: I have no idea.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: This is the crew of the Endurance... Murph... I'm sorry...

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: Where's Emily?

Speaker: wife
Dialogue: Out in the barn. She's been tinkering with your old projects.

Speaker: emily cooper
Dialogue: Dad... I'm sorry... I made some changes to the machine. I think I did something wrong.

Speaker: murph
Dialogue: Do you remember what you changed?

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Good morning. Don't go outside just yet, Mr. Cooper.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Where am I?

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: It's a bit of a coincidence, really. When the rangers found you, we were the nearest facility.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: What's coincidence? What is this place?

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: We have a lot to show you.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: You're OK. We get this from people who move here from planetary colonies all the time.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Where... where are we?

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Like I said. It was a coincidence. There was a facility closer to Earth, but they had a problem, so you wound up here.  This is the Space Station Joseph A. Cooper.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: He was moved here after they found you. He's a little old for a transfer, but they made an exception.

Speaker: administrator
Dialogue: You're a hero, Mr. Cooper. Let's just start off by saying that. It's an incredible and... unexpected honor to have you here with us.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Shoot.

Speaker: administrator
Dialogue: The rangers who found you reported that you had released a sample of an alien life-form into the wild. Which is, unfortunately, against regulations.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: It was last of its kind. Their planet was destroyed.

Speaker: administrator
Dialogue: The rangers attempted to isolate the life-form, but it had already spread out of control. It seems to be thriving.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Because that was the plan.

Speaker: administrator
Dialogue: Whose plan?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: administrator
Dialogue: My assistant tells me you've applied for a position with the exploration fleet.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Feel like I should be pulling my weight.

Speaker: administrator
Dialogue: That's admirable, Mr. Cooper. The truth is, most of the fleet's personnel are automated. There are a small number of crewed ships. But there are great numbers of candidates. Very well trained candidates.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: I was hoping to enroll in a course. Try to get myself up to speed on the new systems.

Speaker: administrator
Dialogue: I don't want you to take this the wrong way, Mr. Cooper -- like I said, you're a hero. But the truth is we have somewhat limited resources.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: No one's heard anything from Brand?

Speaker: administrator
Dialogue: I'm sorry. Officially, she's been listed as missing for over 200 years. Mind you, I guess you turned up eventually, didn't you?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Am I really going to hurt anybody by going to look for her? I just need a small ship. I made a promise.

Speaker: administrator
Dialogue: Listen. Mr. Cooper. You're a hero. You're the oldest man in the human race. Don't you want to take it easy?  Which is why they're never going to let you go off by yourself in a spaceship. I'm sorry.

Speaker: robot
Dialogue: Settings: general settings, security SETTINGS--

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Curiosity. New level setting. 100 percent.

Speaker: robot
Dialogue: Confirmed. Would you like to make any additional changes?

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Sense of humor. New level setting. 100 percent. Wait.  80 percent.

Speaker: cooper
Dialogue: Where do you want to go first?
